subject: Art & Design
title: The Little Black Dress: Fashion's Most Enduring Icon
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Little Black Dress: Fashion's Most Enduring Icon usable.

hook.text: In 1926, Vogue published a sketch of a simple black dress by Chanel and predicted it would become 'a sort of uniform.'

buildup.text: Before Chanel, black was reserved for mourning. She turned it into elegance, simplicity, and effortless style.

discovery.text: The little black dress works because it's a blank canvas: dress it up with jewelry, dress it down with flats.

twist.text: Gianni Versace once said the LBD is 'the hardest thing to design' â€” its simplicity leaves no room to hide flaws.

climax.text: Audrey Hepburn's black Givenchy dress in Breakfast at Tiffany's became the most famous LBD in cinema history.

punchline.text: The little black dress proved that simplicity is fashion's greatest luxury.

quiz.question: Who popularized the little black dress as everyday elegance?
options: Coco Chanel, who transformed black from mourning to chic in the 1920s
Christian Dior with his New Look collection
Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's
